title: The Livehoods Project: Utilizing Social Media to Understand the Dynamics of a City
segmentation: So, as Clay mentioned, my name is Justin Crenshaw.

I'm from the school computer science at CMU, and I'm going to talk to you today about the livelihoods project, which is an effort that tries to look, tries to utilize social media to understand the dynamics of the city.
And this work is done in collaboration with my colleagues.
Rush works, rods in the audience here and also with Jason Hong and Norman City all at CMU.
1st, I'm going to actually.
Talk to you about neighborhoods.

So neighborhoods actually play a number of essential roles in the everyday life of city dwellers, and by virtue of this everyday experience that people have with neighborhoods, most people I think, have an intuitive grasp of the idea of a neighborhood.
However, it can be it can often be difficult for a person to describe concretely exactly what a neighborhood is, let alone to specify with precision where one neighborhood starts and the next ends.
And neighborhoods again, we can try to enumerate these essential services that they do provide.
They essentially provide order to the chaos of the city.
So cities are big and complex and neighborhoods help us organize them.
They help us determine where to live, where to work, where to play.
They provide an area of safe haven from unfamiliar territory.
There also an organizational unit.
It's very critical for city governments to provide adequate services to the citizens that they support.
They can be engines of economic growth and activity, and I think most importantly from my perspective is that they provide a sense of cultural identity to their residents.
So first to set the proper context for the.
After the talk I want to try a brief exercise, so I'd like you to take a few moments and picture what comes to mind when you think of your neighborhood.
Now, unless you're a city planner, chances are you're not imagining.
It's that is the area that's enclosed by a fixed set of boundaries.
Just a show of hands.
Anyone think of something like this?
One OK. What's?
Much more likely is that you're imagining something that looks like this, right?
So we don't tend to think of a city as the dispassionate set collection of fixed boundaries.
Rather, our mental images of the city are shaped by our experiences in it.
When we think of a neighborhood, we think of the shops, the sites, the public arts, the street performers, and the people they give the place, it's character.
And there's a great quote by Kevin.
Image that captures this.
He says every citizen has had long associations with some part of his city and his mental image is soaked in the memories and meanings.
Now Kevin Lynch was an urban designer at MIT and he actually studied the relationship.
Between peoples biased perceptions of the city and the built environment.
So the architecture of the city.
And he asked, he didn't study where he asked residents of Boston, LA and Jersey City to draw the boundaries of their city by hand, based on their own biased memories and what he did.
Is he then aggregated these individual drawings and he created a composite map that represented a cultural view of the different areas of the city.

And a similar experiment was conducted a few years later by Stanley Milgrom, the famous social psychologist of needed Maps of Paris and New York and Milgram wanted to study the psychology psychological processes that govern individuals in an urban environment.
And these Maps of the city, which are called mental Maps or cognitive Maps.
They provide a window into the neighborhoods as cultural entities and we carry around our own biases of how we view the city and its neighborhoods.

And so different people can actually have a different psychological map of the same neighborhood, and actually so the these Maps are encodings of the rich cultural knowledge that we each carry about the city that we live in.
Now, actually this this highlights two different perspectives you can.
Take on the neighborhoods in the city so one can think of neighborhoods as being politically constructed, that is, having fixed borders that are defined by various entities in city government.
Or you can think of these static boundaries.

They're actually important for municipal governments to have some sense of control or instability, but it's also important for us to understand the organic or socially constructed boundaries of the city.
If for any other reason than to study the city as it lived and perceived by its residents.
And so neighborhoods as social constructions can.
They can evolve extremely fast.
In fact, much faster than the boundaries that typically delineate them.
And our mental Maps of the city can actually shift as the city itself changes, and so these mental Maps are quite flexible to the changes that happen in our environment.
And as such, I think these mental boundaries, or these these municipal boundaries can be misaligned with the cultural realities that exist in a neighborhood.
And so the cognitive lab.
That I discussed with you, they can help shed light on this misalignment and can help identify the distinctly characterized areas of a city.
However, this technique is often only yield small scale and partial results.

And so our goal with this project with the livelihoods project is to see if we can identify automated ways for discovering the local knowledge, the cultural knowledge of a city, and the these cognitive Maps actually help elucidate, and so our research questions are.
Can we discover automated ways of identifying these organic boundaries in the city?
Can we extract local cultural knowledge from social media and can we build a collective notion of a cognitive map from data?
And to do this we actually see.
To leverage location based mobile social networks such as Foursquare, these systems let users check in to various locations to broadcast where they are to their social connections.
Very briefly, I'm sure most of you at this conference are familiar with force.

Where but how it works is when you visit a location you want to share, users open their smart phone and search for that location in a list of nearby locations and then they select it and then that's that's the check in and that's then broadcast to their social connections on this site.

So the hypothesis behind our work is that in fact, the character of an urban area is defined not just by the types of places found there, but also by the people who make that area part of their routine, and I think Furthermore, we we hypothesize that by examining the daily check-in routines of users of Foursquare users, we can also identify this character from data.

And there's another excellent quote from Kevin Lynch, who says that the moving elements of a city, and in particular the people and their activities, are as important as the stationary or physical parts.
And so our goal is to see if we can characterize a place by observing the people that visited.
And the approach that we're going to take is a clustering approach, and so we're going to look for clusters of.
Nearby venues that are visited by many of the same people, it's a pretty, pretty intuitive concept.
So the hypothesis that I mentioned to you leads to a set of design requirements for a clustering approach.
And especially what we want is we want the clusters to be consistent of geographically contiguous Foursquare venues.
Clusters should also have a distinct character from one another, and this character should be perceivable by the residents of the city.
Clusters should be such that the venues within a cluster or more likely to be visited by the same users, then venues in different clusters.
So that's the basic outline of the requirements that we're looking for.
So the into.
Mission behind our approach is that.
If you actually watch Checkins overtime, you'll notice that groups of like minded people tend to stay in the same areas, so in fact the.
Orange and the green tend to stay on the left hand side of the map and the pink in the purple on the right.
In which.
You can do is you can aggregate these patterns to compute relationships between the check-in venues.
And.
These relationships we can use graph clustering techniques to identify these natural borders in the urban landscape.
And the clusters that we discover.
We call life fruits so their life words because it's meant to reflect the organic dynamic nature of how we're defining them.
So I'll talk.
About our clustering methodology.
1st.

In order to cluster venues into social, socially meaningful areas, we need a similarity measure on venues that captures the social affinity between them so we can get a notion of how similar two places are by looking at who has checked into them.

To accomplish this, what we've done is modeled venues as essentially a bag of the users that have checked into them, or to be more precise, we model a venue as a vector, and each component counts for a particular user.
The number of times that user has checked in there.
And once we have this model in place, it's a very simple model.
Once we have this in place, we can compute standard vector based similarity measures on the venues and in our work we use cosine similarity.
However, there are problems with this approach.
If we were to just use that as the similarity measure behind our clustering, the first problem is the resulting similarity graph is really quite sparse.
So if you had, for example 100,000 venues in a city, there are over 10 billion possible pairwise similarities.
And if you only have about a million chickens, you're not going to get very good coverage of the data, only using that similarity.
And the second problem has to do with human behaviors in this city.
So the similarity measure tends to be dominated by what we call hub venues.
So for example, nearly everyone in New York has been to Grand Central Terminal.
And so these universal venues that everyone in the city have been to really tend to skew the topology of the similarity graph.
And this turns out to be a big problem.
If you want your clusters to be contiguous as we do.
So again, however, we did mention that we don't just want to use this raw similarity anyway.
Because we do want to use, we do want contiguous venues or to contiguous clusters, and so we'd like to have in our affinity matrix some term to capture geographic distance.
And we accomplished this by restricting the social similarities that we compute to the M nearest neighbors by geographic distance of a venue.
So for example, if venues for venues inj if I is one of Jays M nearest neighbors or vice versa, we will compute the affinity between them via the affinity measure, right?
I mentioned in the last slide, plus we add some small constant Alpha which I will describe in a second.
But otherwise if I&J are far from each other.
We don't compute any affinity.
Affinity is essentially 0 now.
This Alpha, the small constant that we add to our affinity matrix.
It's actually designed to overcome the sparsity problem of the affinity matrix or the acidity measure.
That is, we'd still like some non zero affinity between nearby venues, even when the social affinity is 0.
And so we've we've implemented the affinity matrix in this way.
It blends geographic proximity with the social proximity.
Then, especially once we have this matrix in place, we use standard graph clustering techniques we.
Is the spectral clustering from in Jordan and Weiss NIPS 2001?
I'm not going to go into details of this.
This is pretty standard clustering techniques.
We also use the common technique of looking at the gaps in the eigen values to determine the number of clusters.
However, what we do after we produce the spectral plus.
Is we have a post processing clip step that clears or cleans up any degenerate clusters.
So there are two common to generate clusters with spectral clustering.
One is that the clusters themselves might be disconnected.
So what we do is for each cluster we compute its connected components and if it is disconnected we will make each component its own cluster.
And the other thing that's common is that sometimes you get clusters that are just background noise.
It's definitely common in image segmentation, and it's just it's common in our clusters as well.
And So what we have is if we have a cluster that spans too large of a geographic area, will in fact delete it and re apportion its venues into the nearby nondegenerate clusters.
So pretty simple.
But it's actually pretty effective.
Finally, the last kind of piece of machinery that we add to our system.
Is this idea of related livehood?
So to examine how livelihoods are related to one another for each pair of livelihoods, we compute another similarity score.
This score is nearly identical to the one that I mentioned prior, except it's kind of hierarchically one step above.
So now our bag of checkins counts the number of times a user has checked into any venue within this cluster.
And so this allows us to not only explore relationships among individual venues, but also hierarchically among the groups of venues, the livelihoods.
The data.
So again.
We're using Foursquare checkins.
Foursquare chickens are not public by default, so in fact you can't just go out and crawl Foursquare checkins.
What you can do is crawl Twitter that mentions Foursquare Checkins, so when people post a check into Twitter, we can crawl this data.

So we've done that, and we've combined another data set from IC WSM 2011 of approximately 11 million Foursquare checkins with our own data set of 7 million chickens, and then we've aligned these tweets with the actual Foursquare venue information.
So for each check in we have a venue ID and a venue category.
Before I get into how we evaluate.
This and our results I want to talk briefly about the website that we designed lifewoods.org.
I encourage you to check it out now if you're interested.
We've constructed Maps for several.
We've constructed these life with Maps for several cities currently in New York, San Francisco, Pittsburgh and Montreal, and we're showcasing them on this site.
Livehoods.org so people can interactively explore the Maps.
And you can do things like when you click on a venue it will highlight its surrounding like Hood.
And you can see information about like the types of venues that are in that area.
So this is Soho in New York.
You can also see status.
Takes about that life would and you can see the related life Woods.

Is kind of a fun way to explore various transportation patterns throughout the city.

And so when you're with with evaluation metrics like this, any sort of quantitative evaluation method kind of falls far short of capturing what we're looking for.
And So what we did is we took a qualitative approach.
So really, the best way to go.
Get a clear picture of what's going on is to put some boots on the ground and do some field work and so that's what rozzini did.
We went out into the city and talked to residents in Petsburgh about their neighborhoods and our.
Goal was to see how well our clustering approach captured people's perceptions of the city.
And so we interviewed 27 residents in Pittsburgh.
Residents were recruited through a social media campaign where various neighborhood groups were the seeds.
And we used a semi structured interview protocol that explored the relationship among the life hoods that we built.
The municipal neighborhood borders and their individual perceptions of the city.
So you know these three components that are interacting with one another.
The only major requirement we had on participants was that they lived in their neighborhood for at least a year.
Are interv.

Protocol basically it's designed so that we showed them the livelihoods later in the interview and earlier in the interview we wanted to collect as much feedback from them about how they perceive the city.
So again, each interview lasted approximately one hour.
It began with a discussion of their backgrounds.
We ask questions such as where in this neighborhood is there a shift in feel?
So that's they?
Identify where there might be different distinct characteristics in the neighborhood, or for instance, where in the city can you think of where the borders are changing?
We showed them the library clusters and ask for feedback and we showed them their related livelihoods and we asked for feedback.
